creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund and gift from Dr. Otto Kallir
description: standing female figure who has fabric around waist that she is holding up and partially covers one breast; fabric has geometric pattern
medium: Conté crayon and tempera wash over black chalk on brown wrapping paper
text: Standing Girl is the largest known drawing from Egon Schiele’s short but prolific career. His life played out against the backdrop of Sigmund Freud’s studies of the mind and intense debates about the treatment of human sexuality in the arts. Here Schiele combined confident mastery of line with unflinching examination of psychological complexity, of inward reality and outward appearance. He struck a calculated balance between corruption and purity, between the figure’s clawlike hands and her virginal, downcast eyes.
title: Standing Girl
